title: Memory Mapping - Computerphile
description:
Huge memory addresses mean that not every address is valid. Matt Godbolt explains how the addresses are actually used. 

Computerphile is supported by Jane Street. Learn more about them (and exciting career opportunities) at: https://jane-st.co/computerphile

This video was filmed and edited by Sean Riley.

Computerphile is a sister project to Brady Haran's Numberphile. More at https://www.bradyharanblog.com

comments.author: @JonBrase
comments.comment:
8:42 10 decimal digits ~= 33 bits

One of the reasons 36-bit computers used to be popular was that early on folks doing scientific computing were always asking for 10 digits of precision, and that didn't quite fit into 32 bits. 

So a 64-bit address is equivalent to a bit less than 20 digits.

comments.author: @mikefochtman7164
comments.comment:
Worked a system where programs used 'logical addressing', but some direct-memory-access peripherals always used 'physical addressing'.  So we had some service calls where we could pass a logical address to a system call and it would return physical address.  So we could program the DMA device to read/write data from the programs logical address space.

We quickly learned to allocate such in/out buffers on page boundaries since if we wanted to send more than a page worth of data, it would have to be multiple commands, each with it's owh logical->physical address block.

Some really nitty-gritty computing that.

comments.author: @benjaminclehmann
comments.comment:
You touched on it for communicating between processes, but you can also map multiple virtual addresses to one physical address to save memory on shared resources.

For example, shared libraries that will be used by almost every single running process will only be placed in RAM once (save for any mutable global variables). Similarly, a resource that has been copied but not yet modified can be made copy-on-write, meaning it will only be copied when it actually changes in either copy.

On posix systems copy-on-write is heavily used when a process forks, since to complete the semantics of a fork a child process must have its own copy of the parent's memory. But this is real expensive, and it's typically thrown away almost immediately as most programs exec right after forking without changing the vast majority (or any) of their pages. So they do page table trickery to only copy it in the case where it's actually needed. There is still criticism of fork as an API, but that's a can of worms I'd rather not touch. Undeniably avoiding copies in the common case where fork is immediately followed by exec is a good thing.

comments.author: @jeromethiel4323
comments.comment:
Simplification in science education is essential.  Imagine trying to learn something simple, like Newtonian physics.  And in the first class you are accounting for friction, air resistance, other outside influences, etc, etc.  You'd never learn the basics, because you'd get bogged down in minutia that doesn't matter for understanding the underlying physics.

Later on, you start layering in these things that are in fact real, and do in fact influence the system.  But if you had to do it all at once, your brain would explode.  And that's basic laws of motion stuff.  Imagine now, you are trying to learn something HARD, like thermodynamics.  Good gravy, it's almost impossible to account for all outside inputs or outputs from the system you are looking at.

Another example is basic electronics.  Imagine trying to learn ohms law, when even a simple wire (which is usually ignored) has not only resistance, but impedance as well.  And might capacitively or magnetically couple to the wire next to it!?!?  Yes, these are things you need to account for in design work, but you learn all that AFTER you get the basics down.

comments.author: @custard131
comments.comment:
love this series of videos

on this memory mapping topic though, 

firstly the example of needing to agree beforehand which program will use which address space, the most obvious conflict would be if you wanted to run multiple instances of the same program

i believe it is also used for 32 bit compatibility on 64 bit systems, with 32 bits you only have 4GB of addressable memory, but most systems have more physical RAM than that. the OS/CPU can map pages such that the 32 bit app thinks it is running in the 0 - 4.3 billion address range without it having the physically be in the first 4GB of physical RAM

the final trick is that you can have more pages than you have physical RAM, with the data for those additional pages being stored to disk until it is needed at which point the OS will "swap" it for a different page in RAM

comments.author: @SouLShadow-SLS
comments.comment:
Wow. Worst explanation ever. I love this channel and most videos do a good job breaking technical concepts down to common man understanding. But this is the most roundabout, disjointed and rambling explanation yet. 

The table/cube metaphor works great. Mentioning pages (however accurate that may be) adds a layer of confusion that doesn't do anything to foster understanding here. Also, you could simplify a lot by just using the word "range". As in a memory map is really just a range of addresses that can be translated into different addresses in a very simple and efficient manner. Usually just by simple addition. 

If Program A needs 400 memory slots and the OS knows that it starts at physical memory address Z. Then Program A starts counting it's own address at 0 and, in this simple example, the OS knows that Program A address X maps to physical addresses Z+X, up to the end of the range (in this case 400).

comments.author: @trnsrpd
comments.comment:
I initially thought this was going to be about set-associative caches, the TLB, or swap memory but it's actually about how 64-bit virtual addresses are used. Specifically, it's about splitting a virtual address into sections and using those chunks to traverse multi-level page tables to ultimately resolve a virtual address to a physical memory location.

If you're familiar with DNS resolution (starting from the TLD and working your way down to a full domain), it's quite similar (my impression).

For example, if you have the virtual address 0x00007FFEABCDEF01, the system takes 9 bits at a time (4 times, in the case of Linux with 4-level paging). Each 9-bit chunk indexes into a page table level:

The first 9 bits point to the top-level page table ,
The next 9 bits index into the next level ,
Then the Page Directory ,
Then the Page Table,
And finally, the 12-bit offset gives the exact location in the physical page.


I am curious how this works with swap memory. At which point does it swap. Like at if the 12-bit offset entry indicator is a ternary (valid, free, swap) does it then bring the page from memory?

Edit: I think this is how it works.

Your program generates a virtual address. That gets sent to the MMU(TLB and theres levels like L1 or L2 to TLB) to be translated and becomes Physical Address. That physical address tells the location which is the RAM. Or maybe its cached in L1 or L2. But that's that.

If the TLB can't translate it, then we do a Page Table walk, which is that 9bit traverse thing I mentioned earlier. Now the PTE says whether the VA is in RAM or in disk. If its in RAM get the PA, use the CPU cache and bring that whole page closer to CPU so that your program does something. 
If the data is in disk(swap memory), we first do a page fault and swap using LRU or something and now you have the Physical address after its been swapped, so we follow the exact process as if it was in RAM. If it isn't there, the OS handles it (segfault or something).

comments.author: @rcookie5128
comments.comment: 8:46 Small correction: A Terrabyte is 1000 Gigabytes. 1 Tebibyte would be 1024 Gibibytes, and so one. But Windows uses the 10^n instead of 2^n (bi suffix) words for the 2^n numbers, so it incorrectly writes e. g. 1 Kilobytes, instead of Kibibytes even though they mean 1024 bytes.. I guess the terms are used synonymously often times. 😅
